data.title: Bitwise Diffusion
data.statement:
You are relaxing idly in your airplane seat, thinking about your next CodinGame ClashOfCode, when suddenly, you hear someone shout: "There's a bomb on the plane!"

Everyone on the plane starts panicking. However, you calmly approach one of the air-hostesses and ask to see where the bomb is located. 

As you inspect the bomb, you find that it comprises bomb units attached. You see a 15-minute timer ticking at the top of the bomb and a second screen with the text "Input Passkey (C) :" followed by a few empty squares, which filled when you pressed the keys.

On further inspection, you find <<three numbers>> behind each unit. You quickly figured out that they are the results of certain <<bitwise operations>>. The first number is the result of <<bitwise AND (&)>>, the second, <<bitwise OR (|)>> and the third, <<bitwise XOR (^)>>. You notice that the prompt is asking for the third number. On further inspection of the fine print, you find that your initial assumption was correct.

<<You take note of the following:>>
`There are 3 secret numbers: a,b,c. 
The first number [[x]] behind each bomb unit is the result of {{a & b}}. 
The second number [[y]] behind each bomb unit is the result of {{a | b}}.
The third number [[z]] behind each bomb unit is the result of {{a ^ b ^ c}}.
`

You only have 15 minutes before the plane explodes. You need to think quickly! You decide to pull out your laptop and write code to find the passkey efficiently. From all of your observations, you figure that you need the value of {{c}}. As there are five boxes, <<pad the number with 0s to the left, to make it a 5-digit number.>>
data.constraints:
• 0 < {{x,y,z}} < 65536 (2 left-shifted 15 times).
• All inputs are in <<Integer, base 10>> form, <<not>> in binary.
• Every output is a <<Five-Digit number>>, but may be less than 10000, in which case it is padded with 0s as necessary.
	Example: [[2]] is converted to [[00002]].
data.stubGenerator:
read x:int
read y:int
read z:int

write 2
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> An integer [[x]] = {{a & b}}
<<Line 2:>> An integer [[y]] = {{a | b}}
<<Line 3:>> An integer [[z]] = {{a ^ b ^c}}

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You are relaxing idly in your airplane seat, thinking about your next CodinGame ClashOfCode, when suddenly, you hear someone shout: "There's a bomb on the plane!"

Everyone on the plane starts panicking. However, you calmly approach one of the air-hostesses and ask to see where the bomb is located.

As you inspect the bomb, you find that it comprises bomb units attached. You see a 15-minute timer ticking at the top of the bomb and a second screen with the text "Input Passkey (C) :" followed by a few empty squares, which filled when you pressed the keys.

On further inspection, you find three numbers behind each unit. You quickly figured out that they are the results of certain bitwise operations. The first number is the result of bitwise AND (&), the second, bitwise OR (|) and the third, bitwise XOR (^). You notice that the prompt is asking for the third number. On further inspection of the fine print, you find that your initial assumption was correct.

You take note of the following:
There are 3 secret numbers: a,b,c. 
The first number x behind each bomb unit is the result of a & b. 
The second number y behind each bomb unit is the result of a | b.
The third number z behind each bomb unit is the result of a ^ b ^ c.


You only have 15 minutes before the plane explodes. You need to think quickly! You decide to pull out your laptop and write code to find the passkey efficiently. From all of your observations, you figure that you need the value of c. As there are five boxes, pad the number with 0s to the left, to make it a 5-digit number.
Input
Line 1: An integer x = a & b
Line 2: An integer y = a | b
Line 3: An integer z = a ^ b ^c
Output
The integer value c.
Constraints
• 0 < x,y,z < 65536 (2 left-shifted 15 times).
• All inputs are in Integer, base 10 form, not in binary.
• Every output is a Five-Digit number, but may be less than 10000, in which case it is padded with 0s as necessary.
Example: 2 is converted to 00002.
Example
Input
10
11
3
Output
00002
